sn4.21:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati silāvatiyaṃ.
sn4.21:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans near Silāvatī.

sn4.21:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū bhagavato avidūre appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharanti.
sn4.21:1.3.eng: Now at that time several mendicants were meditating not far from the Buddha, diligent, keen, and resolute.
sn4.21:1.3.comm: As often, here viharanti, literally “dwell”, means “meditate”.

sn4.21:1.4.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā brāhmaṇavaṇṇaṃ abhinimminitvā mahantena jaṭaṇḍuvena ajinakkhipanivattho jiṇṇo gopānasivaṅko ghurughurupassāsī udumbaradaṇḍaṃ gahetvā yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavoca:
sn4.21:1.4.eng: Then Māra the Wicked manifested in the form of a brahmin with a large matted dreadlock, wearing an antelope hide. He was old, bent double, wheezing, and held a staff made of cluster fig tree wood. He went up to those mendicants and said,
sn4.21:1.4.comm: The matted hair and antelope hide are well known symbols of the Brahmins. The “cluster fig tree” (udumbara) was used for ritual vessels, posts, and firewood, and was regarded as Prajāpatī’s tree, a special source of vitality (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 4.6.1.3).

sn4.21:1.5.pli: “daharā bhavanto pabbajitā susū kāḷakesā bhadrena yobbanena samannāgatā paṭhamena vayasā anikkīḷitāvino kāmesu.
sn4.21:1.5.eng: “You’ve gone forth while young, reverends.  With pristine black hair, you’re blessed with youth, in the prime of life, and you’ve never flirted with sensual pleasures.

sn4.21:1.7.eng: Don’t give up what is apparent in the present to chase after what takes effect over time.”

sn4.21:1.8.pli: “Na kho mayaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sandiṭṭhikaṃ hitvā kālikaṃ anudhāvāma.
sn4.21:1.8.comm: Even though these mendicants were diligent, their wisdom was not developed enough for them to recognize Māra.

sn4.21:1.9.pli: Kālikañca kho mayaṃ, brāhmaṇa, hitvā sandiṭṭhikaṃ anudhāvāma.
sn4.21:1.9.eng: We’re giving up what takes effect over time to chase after what is apparent in the present.

sn4.21:1.10.pli: Kālikā hi, brāhmaṇa, kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.
sn4.21:1.10.eng: For the Buddha says that sensual pleasures take effect over time; they give much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.

sn4.21:1.11.pli: Sandiṭṭhiko ayaṃ dhammo akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī”ti.
sn4.21:1.11.eng: But this teaching is apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.”

sn4.21:1.12.pli: Evaṃ vutte, māro pāpimā sīsaṃ okampetvā jivhaṃ nillāletvā tivisākhaṃ nalāṭe nalāṭikaṃ vuṭṭhāpetvā daṇḍamolubbha pakkāmi.
sn4.21:1.12.eng: When they had spoken, Māra the Wicked shook his head, waggled his tongue, raised his eyebrows until his brow puckered in three furrows, and left leaning on his staff.

sn4.21:2.1.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn4.21:2.1.eng: Then those mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. The Buddha said,

sn4.21:2.2.pli: “idha mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavato avidūre appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharāma.

sn4.21:2.3.pli: Atha kho, bhante, aññataro brāhmaṇo mahantena jaṭaṇḍuvena ajinakkhipanivattho jiṇṇo gopānasivaṅko ghurughurupassāsī udumbaradaṇḍaṃ gahetvā yena mayaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā amhe etadavoca:

sn4.21:2.4.pli: ‘daharā bhavanto pabbajitā susū kāḷakesā bhadrena yobbanena samannāgatā paṭhamena vayasā anikkīḷitāvino kāmesu.

sn4.21:2.7.pli: Evaṃ vutte, mayaṃ, bhante, taṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavocumha:

sn4.21:2.8.pli: ‘na kho mayaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sandiṭṭhikaṃ hitvā kālikaṃ anudhāvāma.

sn4.21:2.9.pli: Kālikañca kho mayaṃ, brāhmaṇa, hitvā sandiṭṭhikaṃ anudhāvāma.

sn4.21:2.10.pli: Kālikā hi, brāhmaṇa, kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.

sn4.21:2.11.pli: Sandiṭṭhiko ayaṃ dhammo akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī’ti.

sn4.21:2.12.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, so brāhmaṇo sīsaṃ okampetvā jivhaṃ nillāletvā tivisākhaṃ nalāṭe nalāṭikaṃ vuṭṭhāpetvā daṇḍamolubbha pakkanto”ti.

sn4.21:3.2.pli: Māro eso pāpimā tumhākaṃ vicakkhukammāya āgato”ti.
sn4.21:3.2.eng: That was Māra the Wicked who came to pull the wool over your eyes!”

sn4.21:3.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn4.21:3.3.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha spoke this verse:

sn4.21:4.1.eng: “When a personage has seen where suffering comes from

sn4.21:4.2.eng: how could they incline towards sensual pleasures?

sn4.21:4.3.eng: Realizing that attachment is a chain in the world,

sn4.21:4.4.eng: a personage would train to remove it.”

sn4.22:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati silāvatiyaṃ.
sn4.22:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans near Silāvatī.

sn4.22:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā samiddhi bhagavato avidūre appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharati.
sn4.22:1.2.eng: Now at that time Venerable Samiddhi was meditating not far from the Buddha, diligent, keen, and resolute.
sn4.22:1.2.comm: For Samiddhi, see note on SN 1.20:1.3.

sn4.22:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmato samiddhissa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn4.22:1.3.eng: Then as Venerable Samiddhi was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,

sn4.22:1.5.eng: to have a teacher who is a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha!

sn4.22:1.6.pli: Lābhā vata me, suladdhaṃ vata me,
sn4.22:1.6.eng: I’m so fortunate, so very fortunate,

sn4.22:1.7.eng: to have gone forth in a teaching and training so well explained!

sn4.22:1.8.pli: Lābhā vata me, suladdhaṃ vata me,
sn4.22:1.8.eng: I’m so fortunate, so very fortunate,

sn4.22:1.9.eng: to have spiritual companions who are ethical and of good character.”

sn4.22:1.10.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā āyasmato samiddhissa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya yenāyasmā samiddhi tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmato samiddhissa avidūre mahantaṃ bhayabheravaṃ saddamakāsi, apissudaṃ pathavī maññe undrīyati.
sn4.22:1.10.eng: And then Māra the Wicked, knowing Samiddhi’s train of thought, went up to him and made a terrifyingly loud noise close by him. It seemed as if the earth was shattering.

sn4.22:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā samiddhi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno āyasmā samiddhi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn4.22:2.1.eng: Then Samiddhi went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. The Buddha said,

sn4.22:2.2.pli: “idhāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavato avidūre appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharāmi.

sn4.22:2.3.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:

sn4.22:2.6.pli: Lābhā vata me, suladdhaṃ vata me,

sn4.22:2.8.pli: Lābhā vata me, suladdhaṃ vata me,

sn4.22:2.10.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, avidūre mahābhayabheravasaddo ahosi, apissudaṃ pathavī maññe undrīyatī”ti.

sn4.22:3.2.pli: Māro eso pāpimā tuyhaṃ vicakkhukammāya āgato.
sn4.22:3.2.eng: That’s Māra the Wicked come to pull the wool over your eyes!

sn4.22:3.3.pli: Gaccha tvaṃ, samiddhi, tattheva appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharāhī”ti.
sn4.22:3.3.eng: Go back to that same place, Samiddhi, and meditate, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

sn4.22:3.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā samiddhi bhagavato paṭissutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
sn4.22:3.4.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Samiddhi. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

sn4.22:3.5.pli: Dutiyampi kho āyasmā samiddhi tattheva appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihāsi.
sn4.22:3.5.eng: And for a second time Samiddhi was meditating in that same place, diligent, ardent, and resolute.

sn4.22:3.6.pli: Dutiyampi kho āyasmato samiddhissa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa …pe…
sn4.22:3.6.eng: And for a second time he had the same thought …

sn4.22:3.7.pli: dutiyampi kho māro pāpimā āyasmato samiddhissa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya …pe…
sn4.22:3.7.eng: and Māra made an earth-shattering noise.

sn4.22:3.9.pli: Atha kho āyasmā samiddhi māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.22:3.9.eng: Then Samiddhi addressed Māra the Wicked One in verse:

sn4.22:4.2.eng: from the lay life to homelessness.

sn4.22:4.3.eng: My mindfulness and wisdom are mature,

sn4.22:4.4.eng: my mind is serene in immersion.

sn4.22:5.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ samiddhi bhikkhū”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn4.22:5.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The mendicant Samiddhi knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

sn4.23:1.1.comm: Compare the stories of Channa (MN 144, SN 35.87), Vakkali (SN 22.87), and the suicidal Saṅgha (SN 54.9, Bu Pj 3).

sn4.23:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn4.23:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn4.23:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā godhiko isigilipasse viharati kāḷasilāyaṃ.
sn4.23:1.3.eng: Now at that time Venerable Godhika was staying on the slopes of Isigili at the Black Rock.

sn4.23:1.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā godhiko appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto sāmayikaṃ cetovimuttiṃ phusi.
sn4.23:1.4.eng: Then Venerable Godhika, meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, experienced temporary freedom of heart.
sn4.23:1.4.comm: “Temporary” (sāmayikaṁ) liberation is mentioned at MN 122:4.1, where it contrasts with the “irreversible” liberation of the perfected one. It also appears in AN 6.44 and AN 10.75, and is defined in the Paṭisambhidāmagga as the four absorptions and four formless attainments (Ps 1.5:26.2).

sn4.23:1.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmā godhiko tamhā sāmayikāya cetovimuttiyā parihāyi.
sn4.23:1.5.eng: But then he fell away from that temporary freedom of heart.
sn4.23:1.5.comm: The commentary explains that he was chronically ill, so could not progress in meditation despite strenuous efforts over a long time.

sn4.23:1.6.pli: Dutiyampi kho āyasmā godhiko appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto sāmayikaṃ cetovimuttiṃ phusi.

sn4.23:1.7.pli: Dutiyampi kho āyasmā godhiko tamhā sāmayikāya cetovimuttiyā parihāyi.

sn4.23:1.8.pli: Tatiyampi kho āyasmā godhiko appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto sāmayikaṃ cetovimuttiṃ phusi.

sn4.23:1.9.pli: Tatiyampi kho āyasmā godhiko tamhā …pe… parihāyi.

sn4.23:1.10.pli: Catutthampi kho āyasmā godhiko appamatto …pe… vimuttiṃ phusi.

sn4.23:1.11.pli: Catutthampi kho āyasmā godhiko tamhā …pe… parihāyi.

sn4.23:1.12.pli: Pañcamampi kho āyasmā godhiko …pe… cetovimuttiṃ phusi.

sn4.23:1.14.pli: Chaṭṭhampi kho āyasmā godhiko appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto sāmayikaṃ cetovimuttiṃ phusi.
sn4.23:1.14.eng: sixth time Godhika experienced temporary freedom of heart.

sn4.23:1.15.pli: Chaṭṭhampi kho āyasmā godhiko tamhā sāmayikāya cetovimuttiyā parihāyi.
sn4.23:1.15.eng: But for a sixth time he fell away from it.

sn4.23:1.16.pli: Sattamampi kho āyasmā godhiko appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto sāmayikaṃ cetovimuttiṃ phusi.
sn4.23:1.16.eng: For a seventh time Godhika, meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, experienced temporary freedom of heart.

sn4.23:2.2.eng: “I’ve fallen away from this temporary freedom of heart no less than six times.

sn4.23:2.3.comm: The idiomatic phrase satthahāraka (its verbal form here satthaṁ āhareyyaṁ is reflexive optative first singular) is difficult. The obvious reading is to take sattha as “knife”. However, that yields the sense “knife-bringer”, “assassin”, whereas the use of idaṁ in MN 145:5.32 shows it must be neuter, i.e. it is a thing not a person. Richard Gombrich suggests we read sattha here as equivalent to Sanskrit śvasita, “breathing, life” (see Brahmali’s note on Bu Pj 3:2.49.1), yielding the sense “life-taker”, “breath-stealer”, “deadly weapon”. This agrees with the Vinaya commentary, which explains, “What does it take? Life.” (Kiṃ harati? Jīvitaṁ). Since this idiom is only used in the context of suicide, I use the normal English term.

sn4.23:2.4.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā āyasmato godhikassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.23:2.4.eng: And then Māra the Wicked, knowing Godhika’s train of thought, went up to the Buddha and addressed him in verse:

sn4.23:3.1.comm: Māra uncharacteristically showers the Buddha with praise. It seems he is afraid that Godhika will slip beyond his grasp.

sn4.23:3.3.eng: You’ve gone beyond all threats and perils,

sn4.23:3.4.eng: I bow to your feet, O Clear-eyed One!

sn4.23:4.4.comm: “Light-bringer” (jutindhara) is a curious epithet for Māra to use, not least because it is etymologically parallel to “Lucifer”.

sn4.23:5.1.eng: For Blessed One, renowned among men,

sn4.23:5.2.eng: your disciple who loves your teaching,

sn4.23:5.3.eng: a trainee who hasn’t achieved their heart’s desire—

sn4.23:6.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmatā godhikena satthaṃ āharitaṃ hoti.
sn4.23:6.1.eng: Now at that time Venerable Godhika had already committed suicide.

sn4.23:6.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā “māro ayaṃ pāpimā” iti viditvā māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.23:6.2.eng: Then the Buddha, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, addressed him in verse:

sn4.23:7.2.eng: for they don’t long for life.

sn4.23:7.3.eng: Having plucked out craving, root and all,

sn4.23:7.4.comm: The Buddha confirms that he had attained arahantship, or irreversible liberation, which must have been shortly before he died. The Buddhist tradition says that only an arahant is allowed to take their own life, and only then in cases of terminal illness. However, it is possible to read the scriptural passages the other way. Since an arahant is incapable of doing anything wrong, the fact that they killed themselves shows there is nothing wrong with voluntary euthanasia in cases of incurable and imminent terminal illness.

sn4.23:8.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,

sn4.23:8.2.pli: “āyāma, bhikkhave, yena isigilipassaṃ kāḷasilā tenupasaṅkamissāma yattha godhikena kulaputtena satthaṃ āharitan”ti.
sn4.23:8.2.eng: “Come, mendicants, let’s go to the Black Rock on the slopes of Isigili where Godhika, who came from a good family, committed suicide.”

sn4.23:8.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

sn4.23:9.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sambahulehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ yena isigilipassaṃ kāḷasilā tenupasaṅkami.
sn4.23:9.1.eng: Then the Buddha together with several mendicants went to the Black Rock on the slopes of Isigili.

sn4.23:9.2.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ godhikaṃ dūratova mañcake vivattakkhandhaṃ semānaṃ.
sn4.23:9.2.eng: The Buddha saw Godhika off in the distance on his cot, lying with aggregates cast off.
sn4.23:9.2.comm: Vivatta (or vivaṭṭa) often means “cast off”, as in “the fetters” (vivattayi saṁyojanaṁ) or the “veil” (vivaṭṭacchada). Here it describes the dead monk’s body after attaining final Nibbana.

sn4.23:9.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena dhūmāyitattaṃ timirāyitattaṃ gacchateva purimaṃ disaṃ, gacchati pacchimaṃ disaṃ, gacchati uttaraṃ disaṃ, gacchati dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ, gacchati uddhaṃ, gacchati adho, gacchati anudisaṃ.
sn4.23:9.3.eng: Now at that time a cloud of black smoke was moving east, west, north, south, above, below, and in-between.

sn4.23:10.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,

sn4.23:10.2.pli: “passatha no tumhe, bhikkhave, etaṃ dhūmāyitattaṃ timirāyitattaṃ gacchateva purimaṃ disaṃ, gacchati pacchimaṃ disaṃ, gacchati uttaraṃ disaṃ, gacchati dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ, gacchati uddhaṃ, gacchati adho, gacchati anudisan”ti?
sn4.23:10.2.eng: “Mendicants, do you see that cloud of black smoke moving east, west, north, south, above, below, and in-between?”

sn4.23:10.4.pli: “Eso kho, bhikkhave, māro pāpimā godhikassa kulaputtassa viññāṇaṃ samanvesati:
sn4.23:10.4.eng: “That’s Māra the Wicked searching for Godhika’s consciousness, wondering:

sn4.23:10.6.pli: Appatiṭṭhitena ca, bhikkhave, viññāṇena godhiko kulaputto parinibbuto”ti.
sn4.23:10.6.eng: But since his consciousness is not established, Godhika is quenched.”

sn4.23:10.7.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṃ ādāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.23:10.7.eng: Then Māra, carrying his arched harp made from the pale timber of wood-apple, went up to the Buddha and addressed him in verse:
sn4.23:10.7.comm: For the “arched harp” (vīṇa), see SN 35.246 and notes. Pañcasikha’s harp is described in the same way (DN 21:1.2.4), and tradition says they were in fact the same instrument.

sn4.23:11.2.eng: in the four quarters and in-between,

sn4.23:11.4.eng: where has that Godhika got to?”

sn4.23:12.1.eng: “He was an attentive and steadfast sage,

sn4.23:12.3.eng: By day and by night he applied himself,

sn4.23:13.1.eng: He defeated the army of death,

sn4.23:13.2.eng: and won’t return for any future life.

sn4.23:13.3.eng: Having plucked out craving, root and all

sn4.23:14.1.comm: This verse, which must have been added by redactors, also occurs at Snp 3.2:25.1.

sn4.23:14.2.eng: that his harp dropped from his armpit,

sn4.23:14.3.comm: Māra is referred to as a yakkha.

sn4.24:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre ajapālanigrodhe.
sn4.24:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in Uruvelā at the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
sn4.24:1.2.comm: According to the commentarial reckoning, this was in the fifth week after Awakening.

sn4.24:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena māro pāpimā sattavassāni bhagavantaṃ anubandho hoti otārāpekkho otāraṃ alabhamāno.
sn4.24:1.3.eng: Now at that time Māra the Wicked had been pursuing the Buddha for seven years hoping to find a vulnerability without success.
sn4.24:1.3.comm: This series of verses is a cleverly structured argument where Māra tries one method after another, always seeking to find something in the Buddha’s words or deeds that make him vulnerable. | Siddhattha had practiced for six years and had now only just realized Awakening, so either the number seven has been rounded up, or else Māra began his work before Siddhattha left home.

sn4.24:1.4.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.24:1.4.eng: Then Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha and addressed him in verse:

sn4.24:2.1.eng: “Are you swamped by sorrow <j>that you meditate in the forest?
sn4.24:2.1.comm: Māra begins the contest of wits by insinuating that something must have gone wrong for the Buddha to end up where he is, trying to play on feelings of self-doubt.

sn4.24:2.2.eng: Have you lost a fortune, or do you long for one?

sn4.24:2.3.eng: Or perhaps you’ve committed <j>some crime in the village?

sn4.24:2.4.eng: Why don’t you get too close to people?

sn4.24:2.5.eng: And why does no-one get close to you?”

sn4.24:3.1.eng: “I’ve dug out the root of sorrow completely.
sn4.24:3.1.comm: The Buddha rejoins with a series of bold and incontrovertible claims, shutting down the idea that he is self-loathing.

sn4.24:3.2.eng: I practice absorption free of guilt or sorrow.

sn4.24:3.3.eng: I’ve cut off all greed and muttered prayer for future lives.

sn4.24:3.4.eng: Undefiled, I practice absorption, <j>O kinsman of the negligent!”

sn4.24:4.1.comm: Māra changes tack. Having failed to insinuate self-doubt, now he tries to use the Buddha’s very confidence against him. Surely he must be conceited to make such claims.

sn4.24:5.1.eng: “The things they speak of aren’t mine;
sn4.24:5.1.comm: The Buddha rejects the charge of conceit, as he has merely spoken of the truth, not of what he is attached to.

sn4.24:5.2.eng: I’m not someone who speaks like that.

sn4.24:5.3.comm: The Buddha goes on the attack, asserting the limits of Māra’s knowledge.

sn4.24:5.4.eng: you won’t even see the path I take.”

sn4.24:6.1.comm: Māra accepts, for rhetorical purposes, the Buddha’s claim that he has found a path Māra cannot see. Better, he argues, for the Buddha to walk it alone and not teach anyone.

sn4.24:6.2.eng: that’s safe, and leads to freedom from death,

sn4.24:6.3.eng: go and walk that path alone—

sn4.24:6.4.eng: why teach it to anyone else?”

sn4.24:7.1.comm: The Buddha rejects this final parry, asserting that he will teach anyone who asks.

sn4.24:7.2.eng: ask what’s beyond the domain of Death.

sn4.24:7.3.eng: When I’m asked, I explain to them

sn4.24:8.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhante, gāmassa vā nigamassa vā avidūre pokkharaṇī.
sn4.24:8.1.eng: “Sir, suppose there was a lotus pond not far from a town or village,
sn4.24:8.1.comm: The same simile appears at MN 35:23.4.

sn4.24:8.3.pli: Atha kho, bhante, sambahulā kumārakā vā kumārikāyo vā tamhā gāmā vā nigamā vā nikkhamitvā yena sā pokkharaṇī tenupasaṅkameyyuṃ; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ kakkaṭakaṃ udakā uddharitvā thale patiṭṭhapeyyuṃ.
sn4.24:8.3.eng: Then several boys or girls would leave the town or village and go to the pond, where they’d pull out the crab and put it on solid ground.

sn4.24:8.4.pli: Yaṃ yadeva hi so, bhante, kakkaṭako aḷaṃ abhininnāmeyya taṃ tadeva te kumārakā vā kumārikāyo vā kaṭṭhena vā kathalāya vā sañchindeyyuṃ sambhañjeyyuṃ sampalibhañjeyyuṃ.
sn4.24:8.4.eng: Whenever that crab extended a claw, those boys or girls would snap, crack, and break it off with a stick or a stone.
sn4.24:8.4.comm: The crab “extends” a claw as a meditator after absorption “extends” the mind to insight (MN 4:27.1). See too the simile at SN 35.240.

sn4.24:8.5.pli: Evañhi so, bhante, kakkaṭako sabbehi aḷehi sañchinnehi sambhaggehi sampalibhaggehi abhabbo taṃ pokkharaṇiṃ otarituṃ.
sn4.24:8.5.eng: And when that crab’s claws had all been snapped, cracked, and broken off it wouldn’t be able to return down into that lotus pond.

sn4.24:8.6.pli: Evameva kho, bhante, yāni kānici visūkāyikāni visevitāni vipphanditāni, sabbāni tāni bhagavatā sañchinnāni sambhaggāni sampalibhaggāni.
sn4.24:8.6.eng: In the same way, sir, the Buddha has snapped, cracked, and broken off all my twists, ducks, and dodges.

sn4.24:8.7.pli: Abhabbo dānāhaṃ, bhante, puna bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamituṃ yadidaṃ otārāpekkho”ti.
sn4.24:8.7.eng: Now I’m not able to approach the Buddha again in hopes of finding a vulnerability.”

sn4.24:8.8.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā bhagavato santike imā nibbejanīyā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn4.24:8.8.eng: Then Māra the Wicked recited these verses of disappointment in the Buddha’s presence:

sn4.24:9.2.eng: that looked like a lump of fat.

sn4.24:9.3.eng: ‘Perhaps I’ll find something tender,’ it thought,

sn4.24:10.3.eng: Like the crow that pecked the stone,
